elements.content: A selection of new η8-permethylpentalene zirconium and hafnium complexes are reported. The first d-block metal bis­(permethylpentalene) sandwich complexes, (Pn*2M ; Pn* = C8Me6 ; M = Zr, Hf) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The bis-allyl species Pn*M­(C3H5)2 (M = Zr, Hf) have been synthesized; these complexes are fluxional in solution and react with CO2 to give the double-insertion product Pn*M­(κ2-O2CCH2CHCH2)2 (M = Zr, Hf). We also report monometallic, bimetallic, and polymeric σ-bonded alkyl derivatives such as (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)­(μ-Me)2, [Pn*Hf­(CH2Ph)3]­[Li­(1,4-dioxane)4], and [Pn*ZrPh­(μ-Ph)2­Li­(μ-1,4-dioxane)] n .
elements.clean_text: A selection of new η8-permethylpentalene zirconium and hafnium complexes are reported. The first d-block metal bis(permethylpentalene) sandwich complexes, (Pn*2M ; Pn* = C8Me6 ; M = Zr, Hf) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The bis-allyl species Pn*M(C3H5)2 (M = Zr, Hf) have been synthesized; these complexes are fluxional in solution and react with CO2 to give the double-insertion product Pn*M(κ2-O2CCH2CHCH2)2 (M = Zr, Hf). We also report monometallic, bimetallic, and polymeric σ-bonded alkyl derivatives such as (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)(μ-Me)2, [Pn*Hf(CH2Ph)3][Li(1,4-dioxane)4], and [Pn*ZrPh(μ-Ph)2Li(μ-1,4-dioxane)] n .

elements.content: Pentalene (Pn; C8H6) is a bicyclic carbocycle related to two cyclopentadiene (Cp) units by a ring fusion and to cyclooctatetraene (COT) by a 1,5-transannular bond. COT and Pn are isoelectronic. However, Pn is constrained by its bridgehead bond, forcing a near-planar geometry, and is therefore antiaromatic by Hückel’s 4n definition. Katz et al. proposed, in a manner analogous to COT, that a two-electron reduction of Pn could furnish a 10 π-electron aromatic dianion, which would serve as an exciting precursor and ligand in organometallic chemistry. The ligand can bind in a multitude of hapticities, and here our interest was focused on the η8-bonding mode, whereby the pentalene framework wraps around a metal center and caps off one face of the metal’s coordination sphere. In this instance the ligand can be thought of as mimicking two Cp moieties, however contributing two fewer electrons to the total electron count of the complex, overall being an eight-electron L3X2 ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Pentalene (Pn; C8H6) is a bicyclic carbocycle related to two cyclopentadiene (Cp) units by a ring fusion and to cyclooctatetraene (COT) by a 1,5-transannular bond. COT and Pn are isoelectronic. However, Pn is constrained by its bridgehead bond, forcing a near-planar geometry, and is therefore antiaromatic by Hückel's 4n definition. Katz et al. proposed, in a manner analogous to COT, that a two-electron reduction of Pn could furnish a 10 π-electron aromatic dianion, which would serve as an exciting precursor and ligand in organometallic chemistry. The ligand can bind in a multitude of hapticities, and here our interest was focused on the η8-bonding mode, whereby the pentalene framework wraps around a metal center and caps off one face of the metal's coordination sphere. In this instance the ligand can be thought of as mimicking two Cp moieties, however contributing two fewer electrons to the total electron count of the complex, overall being an eight-electron L3X2 ligand.

elements.content: The η8-bonding mode was first observed by Cloke and co-workers using a substituted pentalene derivative on a tantalum center. The trichloride (η8-PnR)­TaCl3 (R = 1,4-SiMe3) was initially isolated, which was found to undergo sequential methylation. Simultaneously, Jonas and co-workers synthesized group 4 η8-Pn compounds. Treatment of CpTiCl2 with the pentalene dianion gave (η8-Pn)­TiCp, which could subsequently be oxidized by half an equivalent of 1,2-dichloroethane to (η8-Pn)­TiCpCl. The zirconium congener was synthesized by the direct combination of Cp2ZrCl2 and Li2Pn. Reaction with a further equivalent of the pentalene synthon gave the intriguing (η8-Pn)2Zr species, although no structure was reported.

The trichloride (η8-PnR)TaCl3 (R = 1,4-SiMe3) was initially isolated, which was found to undergo sequential methylation. Simultaneously, Jonas and co-workers synthesized group 4 η8-Pn compounds. Treatment of CpTiCl2 with the pentalene dianion gave (η8-Pn)TiCp, which could subsequently be oxidized by half an equivalent of 1,2-dichloroethane to (η8-Pn)TiCpCl. The zirconium congener was synthesized by the direct combination of Cp2ZrCl2 and Li2Pn. Reaction with a further equivalent of the pentalene synthon gave the intriguing (η8-Pn)2Zr species, although no structure was reported.

elements.content: The progress of pentalene organometallic chemistry was initially stunted by the lack of facile syntheses of starting materials, with routes plagued by either low yields/poor purity or the requirement for specialized equipment. However, in 2005, Ashley and co-workers reported a homogeneous, high-yielding synthesis of suitable precursors for permethylpentalene (Pn*; C8Me6), and this ligand has been subsequently used in early d-block and f-block organometallic chemistry. Recently we reported the synthesis of “(η8-Pn*)­MX2” (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) synthons, which we used to make mixed sandwich complexes that demonstrate very high activity for α-olefin polymerization. Other group 4 metal pentalene complexes have shown fascinating reactivity: a Ti “supersandwich” (μ:η5:η5-PnR)­Ti2 [R = 1,4-(Si i Pr3)2] can reductively deoxygenate CO2 to form a dicarbonyl complex, and, more recently, “Pn*Ti” complexes have shown curious insertion chemistry with CO2. Here we report the synthesis of a series of zirconium and hafnium Pn* complexes, such as Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf), (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)­(μ-Me)2, [Pn*Hf­(CH2Ph)3]−, and [Pn*ZrPh­(μ-Ph)2­Li­(μ-1,4-dioxane)] n .
elements.clean_text: The progress of pentalene organometallic chemistry was initially stunted by the lack of facile syntheses of starting materials, with routes plagued by either low yields/poor purity or the requirement for specialized equipment. However, in 2005, Ashley and co-workers reported a homogeneous, high-yielding synthesis of suitable precursors for permethylpentalene (Pn*; C8Me6), and this ligand has been subsequently used in early d-block and f-block organometallic chemistry. Recently we reported the synthesis of "(η8-Pn*)MX2" (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) synthons, which we used to make mixed sandwich complexes that demonstrate very high activity for α-olefin polymerization. Other group 4 metal pentalene complexes have shown fascinating reactivity: a Ti "supersandwich" (μ:η5:η5-PnR)Ti2 [R = 1,4-(Si i Pr3)2] can reductively deoxygenate CO2 to form a dicarbonyl complex, and, more recently, "Pn*Ti" complexes have shown curious insertion chemistry with CO2. Here we report the synthesis of a series of zirconium and hafnium Pn* complexes, such as Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf), (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)(μ-Me)2, [Pn*Hf(CH2Ph)3]-, and [Pn*ZrPh(μ-Ph)2Li(μ-1,4-dioxane)] n .

elements.content: The earliest reports of η8-Pn binding to early d-block metals involved the reports of the homoleptic bis­(pentalene) species (η8-PnR)2M (M = Ti, Zr, Hf, R = H, 2-Me). Unfortunately none of these complexes could be structurally characterized, so the nature of the bonding and, in particular, the question of the total count of 20 electrons could not be structurally investigated. This prompted numerous theoretical DFT, PES, geometry optimization, and symmetry studies on these species. Consequently, the syntheses and structural elucidation of the Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf) would therefore be of great interest, especially due to the high symmetry and high steric demand of the ligand. It was also hoped that permethylation of the rings would assist in the isolation and crystallization of these complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf)

The earliest reports of η8-Pn binding to early d-block metals involved the reports of the homoleptic bis(pentalene) species (η8-PnR)2M (M = Ti, Zr, Hf, R = H, 2-Me). Unfortunately none of these complexes could be structurally characterized, so the nature of the bonding and, in particular, the question of the total count of 20 electrons could not be structurally investigated. This prompted numerous theoretical DFT, PES, geometry optimization, and symmetry studies on these species. Consequently, the syntheses and structural elucidation of the Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf) would therefore be of great interest, especially due to the high symmetry and high steric demand of the ligand. It was also hoped that permethylation of the rings would assist in the isolation and crystallization of these complexes.

elements.content: The synthesis of Pn*2Zr (1 Zr ) was initially targeted via the combination of [Pn*Zr­(μ-Cl)3/2]2­(μ-Cl)2Li·(THF) x (Et2O) y (A Zr ) with an excess of Li2Pn*­(TMEDA) x in a variety of solvents; however, this approach gave no discernible reaction products, even with prolonged heating. As a result, it was initially thought the synthesis of Pn*2Zr (1 Zr ) was unachievable due to extreme steric crowding. However, we later found that reaction of A Zr with LiAlH4 yielded 1 Zr , albeit in poor yield (). In contrast, the synthesis of Pn*2Hf (1 Hf ) was relatively straightforward, by the direct combination of HfCl4·2THF with excess Li2Pn*­(TMEDA) x and subsequent heating, furnishing 1 Hf as a red solid ().

In contrast, the synthesis of Pn*2Hf (1  Hf ) was relatively straightforward, by the direct combination of HfCl4⋅2THF with excess Li2Pn*(TMEDA) x  and subsequent heating, furnishing 1  Hf  as a red solid ().

elements.content: Due to the quality of the crystallographic data, only tentative conclusions may be drawn. It is noteworthy that unlike the previously synthesized Pn*2M (M = U, Ce) the Pn* rings are not disordered over three positions, presumably due to the smaller size of the central metal atom locking the ligand conformation. The average M–Ct (Ct = ring centroid) distance is greater than those for previously reported group 4 Pn* complexes [distances range from 2.080(2) to 2.135(1) Å]. This is thought to arise from the greater steric demand of two Pn* ligands preventing closer approach to the metal center.

elements.content:
Of particular interest is the comparison of the experimental geometries found and those predicted by DFT ab initio calculations, and a selection of bond lengths and angles is presented in .

Despite the extra inductive effect of the methyl groups on Pn*, the predicted distances within the carbon skeleton of Pn2Zr agree extremely well with those found for 1 Zr , as does the predicted degree of folding of the pentalene ligand; however the fold angles have considerable uncertainty, and therefore no strict/firm conclusions should be drawn upon them. The greatest difference between calculation and experiment is seen in the torsion angle between the Pn* ligands [defined as the angle between the planes made up between the wingtip (WT, C2/C6 or C16/C20) carbons and the metal center on each Pn* moiety], where calculations predict the pentalene rings to be more staggered than observed. This can be explained by the extra steric bulk of the Pn* ligand compared to the nonsubstituted analogue, in particular the steric clash of the methyl group on the WT position, with the bridgehead (BH, C4/C8) carbon on the other pentalene ligand. It is expected this would move the energetic minimum of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to a lower torsion angle. 1 M (M = Zr, Hf) are formally 20-electron complexes. The two highest energy electrons would therefore be expected to be found in an antibonding orbital; however the previously mentioned DFT study found the HOMO of the Pn2M species to be purely localized on the Pn framework. 1 M could be expected to have a HOMO of similar makeup to Pn2M, and as such, the slight lengthening in the M–Pn* distances compared to other species reported (vide infra) is attributed to steric factors.

CBH are the bridgehead (BH) carbons, C4 and C8.

Both 1 Zr and 1 Hf exhibit very simple room-temperature 1H NMR spectra revealing two sharp resonances in a 24:12 ratio. This implies that the Pn* ligands can easily oscillate from the torsion angle minima, and thus all the non-wingtip (NWT) Me protons are equivalent at room temperature. 1 Zr and 1 Hf were also characterized by high-resolution mass spectrometry revealing signals at m/z = 462.1864 (1 Zr ) and 552.2288 (1 Hf ) and the subsequent fragmentation of the loss of Pn* from the molecular ion.

elements.content: Organometallic complexes containing the allyl ligand (C3H5) often exhibit varied hapticity and fluxional behavior and have use in the polymerization of α-olefins. Group 4 metal allyl complexes are however often thermally unstable, which has hampered their isolation and characterization, especially in the solid state. Despite this thermal instability, Cp2Zr­(C3H5)2 was synthesized by the reaction of Cp2ZrCl2 with C3H5MgCl. It was found that the allyl ligands were fluxional at room temperature, with no observed decoalescence of the 1H NMR resonances even when cooled to −90 °C. IR spectroscopy indicated, however, that the structure contained mixed-hapticity allyl ligands, and so an 18-electron formula of Cp2Zr­(η3-C3H5)­(η1-C3H5) was assigned.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Pn*M(allyl)2 (M = Zr, Hf)

Organometallic complexes containing the allyl ligand (C3H5) often exhibit varied hapticity and fluxional behavior and have use in the polymerization of α-olefins. Group 4 metal allyl complexes are however often thermally unstable, which has hampered their isolation and characterization, especially in the solid state. Despite this thermal instability, Cp2Zr(C3H5)2 was synthesized by the reaction of Cp2ZrCl2 with C3H5MgCl. It was found that the allyl ligands were fluxional at room temperature, with no observed decoalescence of the 1H NMR resonances even when cooled to -90 °C. IR spectroscopy indicated, however, that the structure contained mixed-hapticity allyl ligands, and so an 18-electron formula of Cp2Zr(η3-C3H5)(η1-C3H5) was assigned.

elements.content: One of the earliest η8-Pn papers was a detailed NMR investigation into the solution phase structure of (η8-Pn)­Zr­(C3H5)2 by Gabor et al. This compound was made in good yield by the combination of (η8-Pn)­CpZrCl with two equivalents of LiC3H5. An NMR investigation elucidated the solution phase structure (implying both allyl units to be bound in an η3-fashion), but geometric details of the complex remained elusive. The Pn* analogue was therefore targeted, along with the Hf congener, as the ligands’ improved crystallizability (compared with Pn) could potentially yield the elucidation of geometric parameters.

elements.content: 2 Zr and 2 Hf are isostructural in the solid state, with both crystallizing in the P1̅ space group with extremely similar unit cell parameters containing one molecule in the asymmetric unit (2 Zr is shown in ). Overall the structural metrics are very similar for 2 M , with slightly shorter M–C bond lengths for 2 Hf , which has been previously observed in other Pn*Hf and Pn*Zr compounds. In the solid state, the allyl units are bound in an η3-fashion, making 2 M 18-electron complexes. The allyl units tilt away from the metal centers presumably to optimize the overlap between the d-orbitals on the metals and the p-orbitals of the allyl carbons (demonstrated by the M1–Ct3–C16 and M1–Ct4–C19 angles, ). The four centroids (two from the Pn*, one from each of the allyl moieties) arrange themselves as a distorted tetrahedral arrangement around the metal center.

elements.content: Due to the previously mentioned thermal instability of group 4 unsubstituted allyl complexes, structural comparisons are limited, with only one example of a bis-η3-allyl Zr in the literature: CpZr­(η3-C3H5)2­(η1-C3H5). The structural parameters agree well with this previous example. Even rarer are structurally characterized examples of Hf allyl, with only four reported, all containing only one allyl substituent. As such, 2 Hf represents the first structurally characterized bis-allyl Hf compound. The Hf–Callyl distances of 2 Hf compare well with the limited examples reported in the CSD.

The structural parameters agree well with this previous example. Even rarer are structurally characterized examples of Hf allyl, with only four reported, all containing only one allyl substituent. As such, 2  Hf  represents the first structurally characterized bis-allyl Hf compound. The Hf-Callyl distances of 2  Hf  compare well with the limited examples reported in the CSD.

elements.content: At room temperature the 1H NMR spectrum of 2 Hf consists of three resonances, a well-defined quintet at 5.16 ppm (J H–H = 13 Hz, part of an AX4 spin system), a sharp singlet at 1.59 ppm, and an extremely broad resonance centered at 1.92 ppm (ν1/2 = 91 Hz; coincident allyl and Pn* methyl resonances). In contrast the 2 Zr spectrum consists of three slightly broadened Pn* resonances of 6:6:6 intensity ratio (δ = 2.07, 1.71, and 1.57 ppm), while the allyl units give five resonances of 2:2:2:2:2 intensity; a multiplet at δ = 5.15 ppm; and four broad doublets at δ = 3.47, 2.45, 1.93, and 1.88 ppm, indicating the ligand fluxionality is partially frozen out. Upon cooling of 2 Zr and 2 Hf , their 1H NMR spectra can be fully resolved into AMNXY spin systems. Full assignment could be made by inspection of the coupling constants between the terminal allylic protons and the central meso proton (J anti = 15 Hz; J syn = 9 Hz) in combination with NOESY 2D NMR, whereby the protons of C20/C17 give a cross-peak with the protons of the C9/C12 Me groups.

elements.content: On warming 2 M , the two NWT-Me proton resonances coalesce to a single resonance concomitant with the CH2 allyl protons becoming equivalent and the multiplet of the central meso proton transforming into a well-defined quintet, coupling equally to all the terminal allylic protons (an AX4 spin system). These NMR data are symptomatic of two possible scrambling mechanisms (). First, the allyl ligands can spin at a rate quicker than that of the 1H NMR timescale, making the NWT-Me proton equivalent and the two sets of anti-/syn- protons equivalent (top scenario of ). The second scrambling mechanism that could occur is the interchange of the anti- and syn-protons, which is hypothesized to go via an η1:η3 transition state.

elements.content: IR spectroscopy of both congeners of 2 M in the solid state (KBr) revealed a strong signal at 3065 and 1500 cm–1, indicative of an η1-allyl moiety reinforcing the proposed η1 ↔ η3 intermediate and possibly demonstrating the fluxionality in is not only in solution. It is noteworthy that there is no evidence for an η1-coordination in the X-ray-derived structure. However, for such a coordination to be observed a substantial amount of the bulk complex would have to be in this coordination mode (ca. 10%), whereas the detection limit for IR spectroscopy is much lower.
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Insertion in Pn*M(allyl)2 (M = Zr, Hf)

IR spectroscopy of both congeners of 2  M  in the solid state (KBr) revealed a strong signal at 3065 and 1500 cm-1, indicative of an η1-allyl moiety reinforcing the proposed η1 ↔ η3 intermediate and possibly demonstrating the fluxionality in  is not only in solution. It is noteworthy that there is no evidence for an η1-coordination in the X-ray-derived structure. However, for such a coordination to be observed a substantial amount of the bulk complex would have to be in this coordination mode (ca. 10%), whereas the detection limit for IR spectroscopy is much lower.

elements.content: Should this intermediate be an accurate description of the scrambling mechanism seen, it was proposed that addition of CO2 may result in insertion of the molecule into the M–C σ-bond and trapping out of this intermediate. An NMR sample of 2 M (M = Zr, Hf) was charged with CO2. This resulted in a swift lightening in color of the solution. The resulting 1H NMR spectrum consisted of seven resonances: three sharp singlets in the region expected for Pn* Me groups (integral ratio 6:6:6), a doublet positioned around δ = 3 ppm (corresponding to the sp3-hybridized CH2 group, integral ratio 2), two overlapping doublets of multiplets at approximately δ = 5 ppm (overall integral ratio 4), and a multiplet at just below δ = 6 ppm (integral ratio 2). These data are consistent with the proposed CO2-inserted species Pn*M­(κ2-O2CCH2­CHCH2)2 (2a M , ). The 13C NMR data also showed the expected low-field resonance for the κ2-O2 CR (δ = 180 and 191 ppm for 2aZr and 2aHf respectively). All these data suggest the bottom scrambling scenario of is occurring.

elements.content: The η1 ↔ η3 allyl conversion would not, however, cause the two NWT-Me environments to coalesce; so the top scenario of must also be occurring. By inspection of the line shape at the point of coalescence in the 1H NMR spectrum, it is possible to calculate the energy barrier for this scrambling mechanism. This was found to be 63.4 kJ mol–1 for 2 Zr and 58.4 kJ mol–1 for 2 Hf (at 43 and 15 °C, respectively). These values are both comparable with that found for PnZr­(C3H5)2 (64.0 kJ mol–1).

elements.content: Addition of four equivalents of MeMgI (in Et2O) to A Zr resulted in the solution changing from golden yellow in color to a ruby red hue. Subsequent workup yielded a red microcrystalline solid in good yield (64%). 1H NMR studies demonstrated there to be two different non-Pn* proton environments, and subsequent single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the structure to comprise a “Pn*Zr” dimer bridged by three groups, two methyl and one methylene unit: (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)­(μ-Me)2 (3 Zr ). To date, it has not been possible to synthesize the Hf derivative of 3 Zr . A parallel synthesis results in the formation of an orange solution, which exhibits three signals in the 1H NMR spectrum in a 12:6:6 intensity ratio. This compound was found to be thermally unstable, decomposing when heated or left at room temperature overnight, either in solution or in the solid state, giving methane gas and an unidentified extremely pyrophoric yellow solid.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of "Pn*M(methyl)" (M = Zr, Hf) Complexes

Addition of four equivalents of MeMgI (in Et2O) to A  Zr  resulted in the solution changing from golden yellow in color to a ruby red hue. Subsequent workup yielded a red microcrystalline solid in good yield (64%). 1H NMR studies demonstrated there to be two different non-Pn* proton environments, and subsequent single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the structure to comprise a "Pn*Zr" dimer bridged by three groups, two methyl and one methylene unit: (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)(μ-Me)2 (3  Zr ). To date, it has not been possible to synthesize the Hf derivative of 3  Zr . A parallel synthesis results in the formation of an orange solution, which exhibits three signals in the 1H NMR spectrum in a 12:6:6 intensity ratio. This compound was found to be thermally unstable, decomposing when heated or left at room temperature overnight, either in solution or in the solid state, giving methane gas and an unidentified extremely pyrophoric yellow solid.

elements.content: We postulate that on addition of MeMgI the dimer [Pn*MMe­(μ-Cl)]2 is initially formed. In the case of Zr, methane is quickly eliminated to give (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)­(μ-Cl)2, which subsequently undergoes metathesis with two further equivalents of MeMgI to form the 16 e– complex 3 Zr . For the Hf congener it is thought that the second metathesis occurs at a quicker rate than elimination of methane, thus forming the species Pn*HfMe2 (), which is unstable to decomposition to unknown organometallic products and methane.

elements.content: Crystallographically characterized μ-Me and μ-CH2 moieties located between two Zr centers are relatively rare. 3 Zr is the first structurally characterized example of a bimetallic system involving three μ-Me/CH2 groups. The average Zr–(μ-CH2) distance (2.268 Å) is slightly longer than examples found in the CSD. For instance [(ZrCpMe)]2­(μ-CH2)2]+[B­(C6F5)4]− has an average distance of 2.234 Å, and for [ZrCp*­(C2B9H11)]2­(μ-CH2) the average distance is 2.182 Å. The average Zr–(μ-Me) distance (2.448 Å) is comparable to literature examples, even for those systems that are cationic.

elements.content: The room-temperature 1H NMR spectrum of 3 Zr consists of four resonances of integral ratio 2:24:12:6 at δ = 2.71, 1.96, 1.92, and −0.36 ppm, respectively. On cooling 3 Zr , no evidence was seen of any decoalescence phenomenon, and it can therefore be assumed that the Pn* rings are quickly rotating about the metal/bridgehead centroid axis. The methylene resonance comes somewhat upfield of other documented examples, showing it to be relatively more shielded. The 13C­{1H} NMR of 3 Zr shows five expected Pn* resonances and two further resonances at δ = 38.9 and 127.9 ppm [corresponding to the (μ-Me) and (μ-CH2) resonances, respectively]. Similar to the 1H NMR spectrum the methylene 13C NMR resonance is shifted considerably upfield; however the coupling constant seen in the decoupled spectrum is typical of a bridging methylene (1 J C–H = 115 Hz). The attempted Hf reaction gave a 1H NMR spectrum consisting of three resonances at δ = 2.10, 1.96, and −0.44 ppm in a 12:6:6 integral ratio. The furthest upfield shift is typical for terminal Hf-Me groups (e.g., Cp*HfMe2 δMe = 0.07 ppm), and therefore the formulation depicted in is proposed.

elements.content: [Pn*M­(Ph)3]− (M = Zr, Hf) were synthesized by rapid addition of PhMgBr (3.0 M in Et2O) to A M , followed by addition of 1,4-dioxane in order to precipitate the magnesium salts. 1H NMR integral analysis revealed the “Pn*M” fragment had been triply arylated, and therefore an initial formulation of Pn*MPh3·Li was proposed. However, structural elucidation revealed that 1,4-dioxane had been incorporated into the structure to give a polymeric structure with bridging 1,4-dioxane: [Pn*ZrPh­(μ-Ph)2­Li­(μ-1,4-dioxane)] n (4 Zr , ). To date, it has not been possible to grow single crystals of 4 Hf .

Synthesis of [Pn*M(Ph)3]- (M = Zr, Hf)

[Pn*M(Ph)3]- (M = Zr, Hf) were synthesized by rapid addition of PhMgBr (3.0 M in Et2O) to A  M , followed by addition of 1,4-dioxane in order to precipitate the magnesium salts. 1H NMR integral analysis revealed the "Pn*M" fragment had been triply arylated, and therefore an initial formulation of Pn*MPh3⋅Li was proposed. However, structural elucidation revealed that 1,4-dioxane had been incorporated into the structure to give a polymeric structure with bridging 1,4-dioxane: [Pn*ZrPh(μ-Ph)2Li(μ-1,4-dioxane)] n  (4  Zr , ). To date, it has not been possible to grow single crystals of 4  Hf .

elements.content: Single crystals of 4 Zr suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a saturated hexane solution slow cooled to −38 °C. 4 Zr crystallizes in the P1̅ space group with a single molecule in the asymmetric unit of the unit cell. A diagram of a monomer unit is shown in A and reveals the metal center to be surrounded by three Ph groups with a lithium cation bound to two of them (through the ipso carbon) in order to charge balance. Presumably 4 Zr binds three Ph moieties in order to minimize its coordinative and electronic unsaturation (binding two phenyl Pn*MPh2 would be a 14 e– complex, whereas 4 M may be viewed as a 16 e– complex). This has already been seen in the dimerization of the starting material A M and its incorporation of LiCl. The Li is solvated by two molecules of 1,4-dioxane, which bridge to another lithium cation in an adjacent monomer unit and thus form a one-dimensional polymer extending in the ab-plane (B).

elements.content: Documented Zr–Ph compounds are common; however, only one is known in combination with a coordinated lithium cation. In this example there are two different Zr–Ph distances [2.367(4) and 2.450(4) Å], due to the former phenyl being bound to a single lithium and the latter bound to two Li cations. The average Zr–(μ-Ph) distance in 4 Zr is 2.403(2) Å, similar to the previous example despite the presence of only one Li. The Zr–C(15) distance in 4 Zr is slightly longer than those found for ZrCp*2Ph2 (2.311 Å) and ZrCp2Ph2 (2.301 Å). Since these examples are formally 16 e– complexes, the slight lengthening in 4 Zr can be attributed to increased steric crowding around the Zr center. The Pn* ligand in 4 Zr is considerably flatter and has longer M–Pn*cent. distances than 3 Zr (fold angles: 27.9(2)° for 4 Zr , average 30.6(5)° for 3 Zr ; M–Pn*cent average: 2.151(3) Å for 4 Zr ; 2.109(4) Å for 3 Zr ). This is due to the greater steric demand of the phenyl ligands compared with the methyl and methylene ligands.

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectra of 4 M consist of six resonances of 6:6:3:8:12:6 integral ratio (corresponding to the three phenyl, dioxane, and the two Pn* methyl environments). Due to the similarity of 4 Hf to 4 Zr spectra and the persistence of 1,4-dioxane within the product, it is proposed that 4 Hf is isostructural with 4 Zr . The presence of a three unique 1H resonances for the Ph ligands implies all three ligands are equivalent on the NMR time scale and the lithium is either undergoing a fluxional process to bind to each Ph or is not bound in the solution phase. The 1,4-dioxane cannot be removed. The 13C­{1H} NMR spectrum shows the presence of 10 expected resonances, and the 7Li NMR shows a sharp singlet (δ = −1.12 and −1.06 ppm for 4 Zr and 4 Hf , respectively).
elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR spectra of 4  M  consist of six resonances of 6:6:3:8:12:6 integral ratio (corresponding to the three phenyl, dioxane, and the two Pn* methyl environments). Due to the similarity of 4  Hf  to 4  Zr  spectra and the persistence of 1,4-dioxane within the product, it is proposed that 4  Hf  is isostructural with 4  Zr . The presence of a three unique 1H resonances for the Ph ligands implies all three ligands are equivalent on the NMR time scale and the lithium is either undergoing a fluxional process to bind to each Ph or is not bound in the solution phase. The 1,4-dioxane cannot be removed. The 13C{1H} NMR spectrum shows the presence of 10 expected resonances, and the 7Li NMR shows a sharp singlet (δ = -1.12 and -1.06 ppm for 4  Zr  and 4  Hf , respectively).

elements.content:
Addition of four equivalents of PhCH2MgCl to A M and subsequent workup results in the formation of Pn*M­(CH2Ph)2 (5 M , M = Zr, Hf) ().

A saturated hexane solution of 5 Zr was slowly cooled to −38 °C over 3 days, resulting in the precipitation of a fine powder. The supernatant was removed via filter cannula, concentrated, and then again cooled to −38 °C. This process was repeated once more to yield red crystals of 5 Zr suitable for X-ray analysis (in 53% yield). 5 Zr crystallizes in the P21/n space group with a single molecule in the asymmetric unit of the unit cell. In contrast to 3 Zr and 4 Zr , 5 Zr exists as a monomeric complex, as shown in . The Zr centers adopt an approximately tetrahedral arrangement.

elements.content: The benzyl ligand is know to bind to transition metal centers in a variety of coordination modes (ranging from η1 to η7) depending on the electron-deficient nature of the metal. Strict assignment of the hapticity was often a fairly subjective issue until Parkin et al. undertook an in-depth investigation into bonding in Zr-benzyl species. This study revealed two ways of distinguishing the bonding mode of a benzyl ligand: first, the deviation of the M–CH2–Ph bond angle from the idealized 109.5° (which can identify between η1 and higher hapticities) and, second, the difference between the M–CH2 and M–CPh distances (which can differentiate between the higher hapticities). To this end Parkin and co-workers introduced the δ value (defined in Figure S1; see ). Using these two values Parkin was able to propose definitive assignment of binding modes of benzyl complexes (summarized in ). The δ values for 5 Zr are in Table S2 (see ) and predict hapticities of η3 for one benzyl, and the other lies between the η1 and η2 definitions. The former prediction is supported by DFT analysis (). Inspection of the molecular orbitals shows only one bonding interaction in the lowest energy of the valence orbitals (HOMO–9, ), and as such, an η1-bonding motif is tentatively assigned.

elements.content: There is a significant difference in Zr–Pn*cent distances within 5 Zr , which is ascribed to the different binding modes of the two benzyl units. The η3-benzyl must align the p-orbital of the near-side ortho carbon (C24) with the d-orbitals of the metal center. This results in a steric clash with the Pn* WT-Me and NWT-Me (C13/C14), thus forcing up this side of the Pn* and leading to a large Zr–Pn*cent distance. The other benzyl does not require such orbital overlap and is therefore able to angle the aromatic ring away from the Pn* ligand, resulting in less of a steric clash. The Pn* fold angle of 28.8(3)° lies between 3 Zr and 4 Zr (average of 30.7(5)° and 27.9(2)°, respectively). This can be attributed to steric considerations, with the trisubstituted 4 Zr being more sterically encumbered than 5 Zr , with both having greater steric bulk than 3 Zr .

elements.content: Unfortunately crystals of 5 Hf suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis could not be obtained; however, following addition to 1,4-dioxane during workup, yellow crystals of an intermediate were formed and identified as [Pn*Hf­(CH2Ph)3]−­[Li­(1,4-dioxane)4]+ (5a Hf , ). 5a Hf crystallized in the Cc space group with a single molecule in the asymmetric unit of the unit cell. This species consists of a triply benzylated “Pn*Hf” anionic fragment and a lithium counterion coordinated by four 1,4-dioxane molecules. Unlike 4 Zr , there appears to be no covalent interaction between the anion and cation within the solid-state structure, and upon exposure to vacuum, the 1,4-dioxane was removed, subsequently precipitating LiCH2Ph and forming 5 Hf (demonstrated by 1H NMR and 7Li NMR spectroscopy). A model of the anion of 5a Hf is shown in .

elements.content: The geometry about the Hf center is approximately square-pyramidal, with the two Pn*cent C(22) and C(15) making up the square base. Of the three benzyl ligands, two are aligned perpendicular to the Pn* ligand [C(22)–C(28) and C(29)–C(35)] and one is lying parallel to it [C(15)–C(21)], which appears to be the result of crystal packing forces. It is clear by inspection of the Hf–CH2–Ph bond angles that all three ligands are bound in an η1-fashion, something that is also confirmed by extending Parkin’s δ parameter to Hf (all of which are over 0.5 Å). The Hf–C­(15/22/29) bond lengths are all comparable to Zr–C(15) in 5 Zr . The Hf–CH2 distances are also comparable to those in the related benzyl compounds HfCp2(CH2Ph)2 [average = 2.29(1) Å] and HfCp*­(CH2Ph)3 [average = 2.26(3) Å].

elements.content: The Pn* ligand of 5a Hf has a considerably increased M–Pn*cent distance compared to 5 Zr (2.169 and 2.108 Å, respectively) as well as a relative flattening of the ligand [fold angles 24.7(6)° and 28.8(3)°, respectively]. This difference is attributed both to electronic factors, with 5a Hf being an anionic complex (it would be expected that the (formally anionic) ligands would be more distant to the metal center in order to minimize repulsion), and also to steric considerations, with 5a Hf having three benzyl groups in the metal coordination sphere compared to two for 5 Zr .

This difference is attributed both to electronic factors, with 5a  Hf  being an anionic complex (it would be expected that the (formally anionic) ligands would be more distant to the metal center in order to minimize repulsion), and also to steric considerations, with 5a  Hf  having three benzyl groups in the metal coordination sphere compared to two for 5  Zr .

elements.content: Following workup and subjection to vacuum, 5a Hf transforms to be structurally analogous with 5 Zr (from careful inspection of the integrals in the 1H NMR spectrum). Both congeners of 5 M exhibit C 2v symmetry in solution, with six resonances in the 1H NMR spectrum of 4:2:4:12:6:4 integral ratio, the three furthest downfield lying in the aromatic region (δ = 6–7 ppm) and the remainder lying upfield in the aliphatic region (δ = 1–2 ppm). The 13C NMR spectra of 5 M exhibit 10 resonances, five for Pn* and five for the benzyl ligands. Latesky and co-workers noted that the coupling constant of the α-CH2 group and the chemical shift of the ortho protons could be used to probe the binding situation of benzyl ligands. The corresponding data for compounds 5 M (M = Zr and Hf) are summarized in . In cases where there is significant π interaction between the benzyl ligand and the metal center the chemical shift of the ortho protons migrates upfield and the 1 J C–H increases relative to those observed for the other benzyl carbons. Both these effects are clearly seen for 5 Zr , where δ = 6.06 ppm and 1 J C–H = 135 Hz, and as such, the proposed η3:η1 binding modes are reinforced. Comparatively, Latesky’s analysis for 5 Hf implies the benzyl ligands are bound with more η1-character than 5 Zr . However, there is a slight increase in the 1 J C–H coupling parameter, and the ortho chemical shift is slightly upfield compared with species where the benzyl is bound in an explicitly η1-fashion; therefore it is likely that the binding mode lies somewhere in between the η1 and η2 modes.

A series of group 4 permethylpentalene “Pn*M” compounds have been synthesized. Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf) present a pair of highly sterically encumbered compounds that do not show disorder in the solid state like their f-block analogues. The rare group 4 bis­(allyl) species Pn*M­(C3H5)2 (M = Zr, Hf) were observed to be fluxional in solution and spontaneously react with CO2 to give the double-insertion product Pn*M­(κ2-O2CCH2­CHCH2)2 (M = Zr, Hf). A series of “Pn*M” (M = Zr and Hf) derivatives containing hydrocarbyl ligands has been isolated. Of particular note is (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)­(μ-Me)2, which has a unique structural motif containing three (μ-CH2) and/or (μ-Me) moieties. Further, the benzyl complexes [Pn*M­(CH2Ph) n ]0/–1 (M = Zr and Hf) display characteristic benzyl ligation ranging from η1:η3 to η2:η2 bonding of the benzyl ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of group 4 permethylpentalene "Pn*M" compounds have been synthesized. Pn*2M (M = Zr, Hf) present a pair of highly sterically encumbered compounds that do not show disorder in the solid state like their f-block analogues. The rare group 4 bis(allyl) species Pn*M(C3H5)2 (M = Zr, Hf) were observed to be fluxional in solution and spontaneously react with CO2 to give the double-insertion product Pn*M(κ2-O2CCH2CHCH2)2 (M = Zr, Hf). A series of "Pn*M" (M = Zr and Hf) derivatives containing hydrocarbyl ligands has been isolated. Of particular note is (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)(μ-Me)2, which has a unique structural motif containing three (μ-CH2) and/or (μ-Me) moieties. Further, the benzyl complexes [Pn*M(CH2Ph) n ]0/-1 (M = Zr and Hf) display characteristic benzyl ligation ranging from η1:η3 to η2:η2 bonding of the benzyl ligands.

elements.content: While providing a range of intriguing and, at times, unique structures, this has also further shown the versatility of the pentalene backbone in group 4 organometallic chemistry, the ligand effectively capping off one side of the coordination sphere of the metal center and allowing for the functionalization of the other side. The manner in which the comparable electronically unsaturated complexes 3–5 are stabilized is interesting, by either dimerization (3 Zr ), overalkylation (5a Hf ), and subsequent polymerization (4 M ) or moving other ancillary ligands toward higher hapticities (5 M ). These differences may instruct other syntheses: avoid the methyl ligand if the expulsion of methane is a viable decomposition route. Be careful of overalkylation, and if this is an issue, preferentially use the benzyl ligand over the phenyl ligand, where higher hapticities are available to stabilize electron-poor structures. Of further interest would be the reactivity of all of these electron-poor complexes toward small molecules, and work toward this end is ongoing.

cln_elements.content:
Addition of four equivalents of MeMgI (in Et2O) to A Zr resulted in the solution changing from golden yellow in color to a ruby red hue. Subsequent workup yielded a red microcrystalline solid in good yield (64%). 1H NMR studies demonstrated there to be two different non-Pn* proton environments, and subsequent single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the structure to comprise a “Pn*Zr” dimer bridged by three groups, two methyl and one methylene unit: (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)­(μ-Me)2 (3 Zr ). To date, it has not been possible to synthesize the Hf derivative of 3 Zr . A parallel synthesis results in the formation of an orange solution, which exhibits three signals in the 1H NMR spectrum in a 12:6:6 intensity ratio. This compound was found to be thermally unstable, decomposing when heated or left at room temperature overnight, either in solution or in the solid state, giving methane gas and an unidentified extremely pyrophoric yellow solid.

Synthesis of Pn*M­(CH<sub>2</sub>Ph)<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (M = Zr, Hf) Complexes

Addition of four equivalents of PhCH2MgCl to A M and subsequent workup results in the formation of Pn*M­(CH2Ph)2 (5 M , M = Zr, Hf) ().

A saturated hexane solution of 5 Zr was slowly cooled to −38 °C over 3 days, resulting in the precipitation of a fine powder. The supernatant was removed via filter cannula, concentrated, and then again cooled to −38 °C. This process was repeated once more to yield red crystals of 5 Zr suitable for X-ray analysis (in 53% yield). 5 Zr crystallizes in the P21/n space group with a single molecule in the asymmetric unit of the unit cell. In contrast to 3 Zr and 4 Zr , 5 Zr exists as a monomeric complex, as shown in . The Zr centers adopt an approximately tetrahedral arrangement.

Synthesis of "Pn*M(methyl)" (M = Zr, Hf) Complexes

Addition of four equivalents of MeMgI (in Et2O) to A  Zr  resulted in the solution changing from golden yellow in color to a ruby red hue. Subsequent workup yielded a red microcrystalline solid in good yield (64%). 1H NMR studies demonstrated there to be two different non-Pn* proton environments, and subsequent single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the structure to comprise a "Pn*Zr" dimer bridged by three groups, two methyl and one methylene unit: (Pn*Zr)2(μ-CH2)(μ-Me)2 (3  Zr ). To date, it has not been possible to synthesize the Hf derivative of 3  Zr . A parallel synthesis results in the formation of an orange solution, which exhibits three signals in the 1H NMR spectrum in a 12:6:6 intensity ratio. This compound was found to be thermally unstable, decomposing when heated or left at room temperature overnight, either in solution or in the solid state, giving methane gas and an unidentified extremely pyrophoric yellow solid.

Synthesis of Pn*M(CH2Ph) n  (M = Zr, Hf) Complexes

Addition of four equivalents of PhCH2MgCl to A  M  and subsequent workup results in the formation of Pn*M(CH2Ph)2 (5  M , M = Zr, Hf) ().

A saturated hexane solution of 5  Zr  was slowly cooled to -38 °C over 3 days, resulting in the precipitation of a fine powder. The supernatant was removed via filter cannula, concentrated, and then again cooled to -38 °C. This process was repeated once more to yield red crystals of 5  Zr  suitable for X-ray analysis (in 53% yield). 5  Zr  crystallizes in the P21/n space group with a single molecule in the asymmetric unit of the unit cell. In contrast to 3  Zr  and 4  Zr , 5  Zr  exists as a monomeric complex, as shown in . The Zr centers adopt an approximately tetrahedral arrangement.
